Name: qin pi
Biological: Fraxinius bungeana, D.C. var. pubinervis, Bl.

Maladies Treated: Urge of defecating caused by infection (tēnesmus)
Swollen and red eyes caused by heat in liver
Contraindications: Although the toxicity of decoction is low, occasionally it can cause nausea and vomiting. Do not use large amount. Large amounts of herb may cause lab animals to enter a sedative state, spasm, coma, respiratory arrest, and death. Qin pi is mainly used for acute bacterial infection of the intestine, and should not be used in chronic diarrhea caused by pixu (spleen deficient) or shenyangxu (kidney yang deficient) as it may further weaken the body. Incompatible with wu zhu yu (吳茱萸).
Notes: Do not use in chronic conditions without signs of damp heat. Large amounts can cause adverse effects in lab animals.

Name: jiu cai
jiu bai
xie bai
Pronunciation in Japanese: nira (kanji: 韮; hiragana: にら; katakana: ニラ)

Maladies Treated: Sweating during sleep due to liver-kidney yin deficiency
Medical Function: Jiu cai extract inhibited cancer cell growth and induced apoptosis in vitro
Sulfur compound helps absorb vitamin A and B1

Effect on cardiovascular system: sulfur containing substance and ascorbic acid improves activities of endothelial nitric oxide synthase (eNOs) promoting vasodilation, lowering blood pressure, improving capillary circulation, and anti arterio-sclerosis
May inhibit stomach and esophagus cancer
Oral administration of jiu cai extract significantly reduced lung metastases
Dosage: 100 g to 200 g per meal. Seed used in decoction: 6~12 g; or make into powder or pills.
Samples of Formulae: jiu zi wan 韭子丸《聖濟總錄》
Contraindications: Not suitable for those who are yinxu (yin deficient). It contains coarse fiber which is not easy to digest, excess intake can irritate the intestines and cause diarrhea. According to Ben Cao Gang Mu, eating too much jiu cai can lead to blurry eyesight and confusion or even coma. It should be avoided especially after drinking alcohol. High oxalic acid content may cause calcium oxalate kidney stones, affecting those with metabolism issues such as diabetes. Calcium oxalate can damage the kidneys and cause coma.
Research: Study on Cell Agglutination and Sugar-inhibiting Action of the Lectin from jiu cai

Chemical Ingredients: Four new steroidal saponins have been isolated from the seeds: 26-O-β-d-glucopyranosyl-(25S,20R)-20-O-methyl-5α-furost-22(23)-en-2α,3β,20,26-tetraol 3-O-α-l-rhamnopyranosyl-(1→2)-[α-l-rhamnopyranosyl-(1→4)]-β-d-glucopyranoside
Vitamin C, B1, B2, niacin, carotene, carbohydrates, minerals, high level of fiber

Name: luo bu ma 羅布麻
Other name: yang tu la jiao 羊肚拉角

Medical Function: Hypotensive: inhibits angiotensin II-induced contraction via its superoxide scavenger scavenging properties and nitric oxide releasing effect
Dosage: Take orally. For decoction 5 - 10 g. Or use as tea leaves.
Samples of Formulae: (1) For hepatitis and flatulence: luo bu ma 6g, gua di 4.5g, yan hu suo 6g, ding xiang 3g, mu xiang 9g. Make into powder, take 1.5g twice daily with boiled water. 《新疆中草藥手冊》 (2) For treatment of neurasthenia, vertigo, sequelae from concussion, palpitation, insomnia, hypertension, cirrhosis with edema: luo bu ma 3-9g, steep in boiling water as tea, do not boil. 《新疆中草藥手冊》
Contraindications: Long term usage may be toxic to kidneys.
Research: Vasodilation induced by luo bu ma extract is endothelium-dependent and mediated by endothelium-derived hyperpolarizing factor, which involves the activation of K(+)-channels. The higher concentrations of luo bu ma extract may enhance NO production/release to cause vasodilation.[1]
Notes: Classical medical text references: 《江蘇植藥志》: 'The sap of the plant can be used to heal wound.' 《中國藥植圖鑒》: 'The young leaves, after stir frying and rubbing can be used as tea leaf substitute. It is cooling and can be used to prevent dizziness, and is cardiac stimulant.' 《陝西中草藥》: 'The herb is cooling, heart strengthening to promote urination, lowering blood pressure, and for treatment of heart diseases, hypertension, neurasthenia, and nephritic edema.'

Maladies Treated: Heavy bleeding in the vagina not during menses
Medical Function: Taken internally, it can attach the toxic substances and abnormal substances from fermentation in the digestive tract.
Local protective action on inflamed gastric and intestinal mucosa
Hemostatic action on gastrointestinal tract bleeding
Doses of 20, 40g/kg introduced into the stomach can shorten coagulation time in mice (using capillary method) and plasma recalcification time in rats
Inhibition of ADP-induced platelet aggregation in rabbits and rats and intravascular ADP-induced platelet thrombus formation in mice
Dosage: Internal use: in decoction: 9 to 12 g; also can be put into pills or powder form. External use: grind into powder and apply to affected areas.
Contraindications: Antagonistic with yuan hua (芫花), incompatible with da huang (大黃).
Notes: ADP (adenosine diphosphate) is one of the earliest discovered and most important substances that induce platelet aggregation in the body. In vitro experiments can observe two types of platelet aggregation induced by ADP.
